text: So I'm an international student from Canada, and I've recently received an offer from ICL for Chemistry MSci and an offer from U of T for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
I am having trouble deciding on which offer to take
My main dilemma stems from the fact that I like physics and chemistry both very much (leaning a bit towards physics), and I'd like to keep the options of doing both in the future (ie PhD) open
For context I would like to go into some type of research as a career
U of T has much more freedom in terms of my degree

For instance, I can potentially double major in Physics and Chemistry or specialise in Physics and major in Chemistry or vice versa (At U of T you need at least 2 majors to graduate, and 1 specialist = 2 majors)
Imperial has a lot less freedom, though I can easily change to Chemistry with Molecular Physics as long as I take the prerequisites
I just don't know if at Imperial I'll get a good enough foundation in maths and physics to actually pursue physics at the graduate level in the future if I wish to
However, I've visited both and I preferred Imperial (aside from the program) over U of T
* Counsellor highly recommends Imperial (it will be more challenging intellectually, as he says)
* London!! the city is much more international and metropolitan
* Larger classes, at least in first and second years, support not as abundant as at Imperial
* First year is mostly introductory, which I have already gone over via APs
I want to keep the option of working physics and chemistry open in the future
Should I go to Imperial, which is less flexible, but I liked more in general, or to U of T, which I did not like as much, but offers more freedom?
Hello, recently saw two people comparing UCL and Yale in the comments of a post
Essentially the Yale guy made it seem as if Yale was on a completely different level to the likes of UCL, and that the only unis that really compared to Ivy League universities in the US are Oxbridge

I was under the impression that top, non Oxbridge unis like imperial, ucl, Edinburgh and (maybe) KCL were all well-regarded and atleast respected, I mean UCL is currently ranked 9 on QS and ICL is ranked 6th
Does this mean absolutely nothing? Are we all working hard to get into and study in sub-par universities? I wasn't aware the general perception on our universities was this low
I can't believe I saw UCL being slandered so hard
I was under the impression that ICL, LSE and UCL are what would be comparable to most of the ivy League universities, while Oxbridge would be comparable to things like harvard, Stanford and MIT
So which one is it? Are UK unis overrated on league tables or are they just underappreciated by most people?
I want to apply for physics and I'm hopefully looking to get predicted 4A* in maths FM chemistry and physics
My gcses aren't that great tho (only have 9999887766 with 6s in English language and spanish) though I do qualify for imperial's contextual scheme through my postcode

Imperial says that if I do good enough in the admissions test and interview, and if my personal statement 'shows sufficient motivation' , I'll get a guaranteed offer though icl I don't think this is even possible since there's no way that just meeting a few criteria can guarantee me an offer.
I got an offer from imperial college London for medical biosciences, I’m not sure whether I should go
To be honest, I wasn’t expecting an offer back and my heart was set on Computer Science with AI at York
I’m not sure which course will give me better job opportunities
I know ICL is ranked higher, but is medical biosciences as good of a course?
I recently received a conditional offer from Imperial College London (ICL) for Visual Computing and Robotics
I'm thrilled, but the offer requires me to achieve a Grade 2 in STEP Paper II
The issue is, even if I take the exam in June, the results won't be released until mid-August
* **Deadline Pressure:** I would have to reject offers from other universities before knowing the STEP result
* **Scholarship Dilemma:** Securing a scholarship is challenging without a confirmed offer letter, especially waiting until mid-August
Therefore, I'm wondering if it's possible to request an exemption for the STEP Paper II exam
Has anyone had experience asking for an exemption from STEP Paper II at ICL?  Any tips on navigating this situation? Thanks in advance for your help!
* I got 4A\* for my A Levels in Mathematics, Further Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry
* I received some awards in some mathematical olympiad competitions
I wonder if this information would help to support my request
Of course Imperial is the best for CS grad prospects, but i've heard such bad things about the social life and student experience..
I'm fine doing STEP and l'm thinking about switching UCL or Bath with ICL
My thought process is assuming I am rejected from Cambridge but get in everywhere else
Should I switch? What do people think about ICL? Is it really that bad?
I also visited the campus and the Comp Sci building is especially grim looking...
I’m applying to cambridge CS as well as St Andrews, Bath, UCL, Durham

Of course Imperial is the best for CS grad prospects, but i’ve heard such bad things about the social life and student experience… I’m fine doing STEP and I’m thinking about switching UCL or Bath with ICL
My thought process is assuming I am rejected from Cambridge but get in everywhere else
Should I switch? What do people think about ICL? Is it really that bad?
I also visited the campus and the Comp Sci building is especially grim looking…
[just got an invitation from Imperial for the Aero\/EEE Mat test, which is confusing because i was also previously invited to test in November 2023 and thereafter completed my interview

Am I being reinvited to test for whatever reason or is this a glitch? \(aka should i contact ICL, even though the email SAYS not to email them HAHA\)](https://preview.redd.it/igbbcyfdgefc1.png?width=2296&format=png&auto=webp&s=05af75887e61483fd34ad1fa457557ad8a95dc4d)
UPDATE: i emailed and they replied that it was an error and can confirm i am an offer holder...so maybe formal bread post tmr morning? really have to sleep now tho ITS ONE AM I HAVE WORK TOMORROW AHH

Hello r/6thForm, I’ve just begun to look into what uni I want to go for and noticed that imperial has a very low application success rate despite having high grade requirements that presumably few are able to achieve
I have slightly better grades than those required and would quite like to get in, how do I distinguish myself from others, what can I put in my PS that ICL is looking for?
this is actually why i never abbreviate imperial in case people think i mean i can’t lie
hehe Imp is so funny tho it reminds me of those tiny goblins
hi, canadian here! which country do you plan on permanently staying/working in? take that as your first factor because if you decide on moving to the uk then I think it's best to start uni there
I also hold offers for both russell groups and uoft but I'll agree that I don't like uoft either haha
“Lots of snow during winter” since when is that a pro ?
I'm actually in exactly the same situation as you! Sorry for the incoming rambling, I'm really tired today
I feel like the student to teacher ratio at UofT isn't as bad as it might seem
However, there's several hundred people per undergrad lecture from what I've read, which is likely to dampen the support system

I believe they make allowances if you have evidence of the fact that you've already taken the subject (for example, I'm doing the IB and other ex-IB students have been able to get credits for IB classes)
I like my accomodation at UofT, so no complaints there
Which one are you not happy with? Have you looked at the Imperial accomodations?

The thing about UofT is that it's probably easier to do well in (based on admission rate of about 43% versus Imperial's 15% and Toronto having slightly lower requirements), but it's also possible that you'll drop out or not get into the classes/program you want the next year at Toronto if you don't do well
Imperial is probably a bit more challenging because of the high-achieving students in a structured course
If time is a consideration: most undergrad degrees at Imperial take 3 years wheras UofT usually takes 4
What about prices? What are you planning to do after (further study/job)?

Will there really be more opportunities to engage in undergrad research opportunities in Imperial? I don't know the situation in chemistry/physics specifically but I thought that in general universities in the UK offer substantially less such opportunities when compared to those in North America
Keep in mind that the a higher level of research very often does not imply more opportunities for undergrads
I doubt Imperial is that much more highly regarded in academia
Very few people in academia seriously care about rankings like QS if that's where the impression of prestige comes from
Besides, you are just an undergrad so it doesn't matter that much
You are Canadian too and nobody will look down on someone doing undergrad at the top university in their home country
You clearly care about your academic life a lot and I feel the same
If I were you, the freedom UofT offers would be quite important
To me, the slightly dip in prestige is trivial before this factor
I don't really understand why people go to 'higher-tier' unis because they want to be intellectually challenged
You can always challenge yourself if you are motivated enough, but if it is forced upon you, things might go sour quite quickly
Haha glad to find someone in the same place as me! In general, I’ll be very happy to work in either Canada or the UK, but I suppose there’s be more international opportunities I suppose
And you’re right, I’m not picky about the double major as long as I’ll study the two fields to a similar level at ICL, or be prepared to to do so.
Haha a bit of a joke, but I am pretty much a polar bear incarnate lol
How do you find U of T by the way
I would like to go into research in the future
I’m not exactly sure in which area but it’s definitely going to be physics, chemistry, or something in between, so the ability to keep both options open is really important for me
I’ve visited Victoria College and I wasn’t very satisfied with the double rooms that most first year students will be housed in
At imperial, dorms are mostly single if I remember correctly and even if they’re double, there should be separate rooms with lockable doors
Dorms at Imperial are also a bit newer than at Victoria

My main ask is whether Imperial will prepare me to go into both physics and chemistry even though its program (Chemistry with Molecular Physics) is less flexible than say doubling in Physics and Chemistry at UofT

However, I have a hunch that since chemistry and physics have a lot of overlap (especially physical chemistry), studying chemistry will still give you a lot of the same core knowledge at least for maths
What’s more my program has a heavy emphasis on molecular physics, so definitely lots and lots of QM stuff, and therefore more maths
I think hat’s probably going to make it quite easy to switch between physics and chemistry in the future, and if that’s true, there’s not really a point to double majoring at U of T
Also, it’d be heart wrenching to miss the opportunity to study at White City! Absolutely world class research facilities there in reach of all chemistry undergrads!
I feel like ICL will be able to offer a lot more opportunities
After all it is so highly regarded with so much world leading research which is a big step above U of T
There's certainly a lot of overlap between the two in some areas.
OP did mention that first year at UoT would be covering stuff they already did
The main issue is that I’ve visited U of T, and I did not really like the school, so that’s putting me off
Research at Imperial is definitely more available for undergrads from what I’ve seen
Most students in year 2 and above get summer research placements, and you move to the White City campus in year 3, which is really research oriented
Anything in particular you want to know about btw ? My opinions of this uni change like every 10 minutes cause it depends entirely on my mood, and I attribute my mood to the uni
If you're thinking of going into research, there's a good chance you'll end up doing a PhD
And if you do, you could always apply to the uni you didn't attend :)
Unfortunately, I applied to biochem at Imperial, so I'm not sure what Chemisty and Molecular Physics covers.
Then I feel like it's mostly about your priorities and I don't think anyone here can tell you what you value more
The only thing we can do is to give you information
Does UofT not accept transfer of AP credits? If not, are you sure you really won't learn anything new in those courses during first year?
Mainly in terms of the teaching quality, availability of support, office hours, course load…
You’re doing Maths, so what are some things you learn in the first year? How do you find it? Is it quite rigorous and theoretical etc
U of T does accept AP credits, but the specifics I’m not too sure about
They only count for 0.5 credits so definitely not an entire year
At Imperial still you do learn a lot more though
For instance you’d get straight into QM and some higher level maths like Fourier and PDEs, so I’m super excited about that
Quality of teaching varies a lot depending on the professor
Some profs are some of the friendliest and most passionate people I’ve ever met, and I’m doing a one-one course with a prof this summer
Some profs are great expositors but assign evil hw and tests
And one prof is the reason I left statistics all together
It feels like I’m all on my own in terms of like uni life cause I don’t think I’ve much friends
If you mean like support in terms of like uh discussion forums, those exist and are very very useful imo
In terms of course load, I’m terrible at managing my time hence why my current response
But it’s pretty stressful for me and it’s a lot of work
And coupled with tests like every week it’s very very draining.
QS looks at quantity and quality of research and UCL has about 30 Nobel prizes (3rd highest in UK, like 6th in Europe) and Yale has about 50 (7th in the US)

It's also worth noting that all international rankings skew quite a bit towards English speaking unis because part of the rankings are literal individual professor ratings/opinions on the universities in the table and when like half of them are from English speaking countries they're going to have more collaborations/connections to other universities that are primarily English
Also, you can't ignore the funding disparities between the entire world and the US

Oxbridge's endowments are on par with the smallest ivies and decent state flagship schools, and don't come anywhere near to top US unis, and places like UCL even if very wealthy within Europe pale in comparison to the funding available at basically all state flagships and even smaller schools

The quality of the academics and teaching can be the same but the reality of having to be far more careful with your money and trying to bet on lower risk research directions in a field like academia is always going to lose to a funding environment that is able to take larger (and potentially massively rewarding) risks.
I mean you can't really compare them because they're different systems, it depends where you want to work, career aspirations and a bunch of things really
In the UK you specialise earlier, so you develop a deeper understanding of your subject in many cases
I personally prefer the UK system, but honestly its so subjective.
Americans think that anything American is the best thing in the world
This is a country that calls its National basketball champions “World Champions”
UCL is 22 ICL 8th Oxford 1st and Cambridge 5th
Can't tell you what to think but yes ICL and UCL are very well respected
ICL is STEM only so it wont build up the same reputation as Oxford and Cambridge in that regard
U r asking is British university overrated on a sub of people applying for British university? (UCL no diff in education)

I'd like to add the context that I, myself, didn't apply to any US unis (tuition is way too expensive and I frankly wouldnt get into any place of equal quality to the places I had a chance to in the UK)
no, in the US, you have harvard, yale, princeton, stanford, mit and then below them is like the rest of the ivy's + uchicago

I'm not slandering UCL, I think its a great uni, but the sheer difference in terms of how much effort it takes to get into it versus HYPS or even the other ivy's and uchicago, or even the tier below them is what is influencing how I see the unis, which I understand isn't the right way to go about things
In terms of how well known they are, internationally, well HYPSM is probably more so than oxbridge, but I have no doubt that oxbridge teaching and learning far exceeds any in the US

I think in the UK, it is seen as Oxbridge, and just below them UCL/Imperial/LSE/(maybe)Durham, but once you look at it from a wider lens, you fit in uChicago, Columbia, and Brown maybe above some of them? Idk
Overall, I think UK universities tend to be under appreciated - anything outside of Oxbridge and UCL/Imperial and theyre nowhere to be found
(I also personally dont really mess with the QS rankings (I saw them rank MELBOURNE above YALE FFS))

Ultimately, its not that deep, I'm not calling UCL sub par by any means, its just that because I have seen the application process to HYPSM universities first-hand, that I add this additional level of subjective superiority to those universities
You can also check the average salaries coming out of those universities, and it is sadly pretty stark the differences between US/UK unis in general in terms of average salaries
That being said, I've also seen some really smart people getting rejected from (insert random unknown american university here), and that hasn't made me think any better of that university
TL/DR: UCL > some ivys, for sure <Yale, Harvard, Princeton, MIT - but I have this additional layer of subjective superiority in my perspective due to seeing the application process firsthand
Edit - I love UCL, pls give me an offer
yale is a LOT more compettetive than UCL - id argue only LSE oxbridge Imperial are on par or close with ivies in terms of difficulty of admission
Yale is a part of what American college students call HYPSM (Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Stanford, MIT) which are the 5 best universities in the US
Generally, only Oxbridge have the overall reputation of these unis (given the us is a larger country with more people, they have more “top” unis)
I’d say LSE, ICL, and maybe UCL are on the level of the other ivies
For example, LSE and Columbia offer many dual degrees together

Overall, yes, LSE, ICL, UCL are Ivy League level universities, but they are a step down (in general, in specific fields this isn’t always the case) from Oxbridge, which is equivalent to HYPSM in the US
Your intuition is correct, you’re just underrating Yale as it is often seen as peers with Harvard and MIT.
Bruh I pondered this when I got into UCL for an MA
I’m going to be honest with myself here… probably wouldn’t have been accepted into Yale for the same course
That said, research wise, UCL probably exceeds Yale at this point
Depends on how you measure it, but the Ivies are simply more prestigious in general at least in the international education market which I work in.
I would firstly say that most employers would say that Yale >> UCL
I’d also say also in terms of leagues of the uk unis, Oxbridge is first, then LSE / ICL, then Durham, St Andrews and UCL
Though out of that third league UCL gets closer to the LSE / ICL league when looking at international reputation
They are still brilliant unis ranked at the top of one of the best university countries in the world
It’s just Harvard, Stanford, Yale, Princeton and MIT are above UCL…
I'm not american  im british - check my other comment for my explanations for my hideous actions
I never want to be thought of as defending the yanks.

If it is judged based on application and addmission, would it help if the top UK universities make it as difficult as the US colleges? It is well known that sheer luck plays a part in successful admission into US colleges, whereas UK unis adopted a more well defined process based on the academic merit of applicant
A lot of people don’t trust international ranking systems like QS and THE, but they forget that without these systems, there is no reference for applicants at all.
But I’d like to move UCL down a bit in terms of international prestige
When it comes to STEM ICL outranks it and is also better known in other countries, and for social sciences LSE outranks UCL
I’d also say with UoC there’s CalTech and UC Berkeley…
Choosing Yale over smth like Harvard or Stanford isn’t crazy but choosing UCL over Harvard would very much be
Then by that logic MIT is atleast 3 or 4 tiers below the top Chinese and Indian unis
(just by judging how difficult it is to get in)
It's significantly harder to get into Tsinghua or an IIT than MIT

British universities are engineered to reduce competition (oxbridge basically doubles their acceptance rate since they don't allow you to appl yo both while the rest benefit from only being apply to 5 places)

You don't need predicted grades to apply to Yale and there is massive grade inflation in the US where at many middle and upper middle class state schools over 1/2 the class has the equivalent of A\*A\*A\* type grades but when the they take the SAT/ACT it shakes out a bit more
That's why Yale and friends are going back to requiring testing next year.
Its more competitive because theres way more people in america
There is a lot more competition for top places in the US because (as others have pointed out) anyone that has the money or gets a waiver can apply and there are a lot more people
In the UK you have minimum entry requirements and UCAS limits you to 5 choices (and only one of those can be Oxford or Cambridge)
Moreover, difficulty in gaining admission is not the same as quality of academic research, employment outcomes, quality of education, etc.

If you were going to make a HYPSM of Europe what do you think would be in it? I would probably say Oxbridge, UCL or ICL, Paris, and TUM or LMU in Germany; but ETH Zurich also obviously has to fit in there somewhere so I'm not sure.
Suggest that you fix it fast before it gets worse.
Yh UCL doesn’t come close to the competitiveness of ivy.
Most people, and I can certainly say I, prefer the UK's application system, because you get judged on relevant factors - not how many volunteering hours you did
You also have to consider the fact that US unis are private, for profit institutions

Defo more cons than pros, but one of the benefits is they are able to invest a lot more into their education and facilities - I'm not saying its a good thing to be private, as it perpetuates systemic inequality and is all around horrible for everyone, but there are reasons
Furthermore, the reason why I dont mess with int'l rankings is because no one takes them seriously
Everyone already has a notion of the best universities in the world and no ranking is going to change that
But mOST IMPORTANTLY, being WORSE than YALE does not mean the university isn't one of the best in the world
YALE IS INSANE - and I'll say the same for all HYPSM universities
UCL being below them doesnt make UCL worse, if anything, being mentioned close to them puts UCL at quite a good stead.
THE UNI ykwim? but yes we agree yale > ucl
i also think ucl, in terms of int'l prestige, is probably on par with lse and imperial, coming from an int'l perspective myself
id personally defo put caltech in HYPSM with mit, (mit is where caltech rejects go!)
being smart is not sufficient to get into mit, you also have to be a debater, MUN captain, volleyball captain, cross country captain
either way, from an international standpoint, HYPSM + Oxbridge still quite a bit ahead of anything else.

that’s true but even without that yale is more competitive bcuz no one is getting into yale just bcuz they have high grades u have to have a bunch of extra things but ucl u can get into just by meeting the predicted grade requirements(you don’t even need to have a good transcript/gcses u just need a good predicted whereas in the us they look at every grade uve gotten in the past four yrs)
It's actually the opposite from what people who study at both have said
British students are a good bit above americans when it comes to their subjects because we specialise into 3/4 subjects at 16
I don't think this logic applies to the top american unis since those guys probably self studied what we do, but on average it's definitely true
I mean LSE offer dual degrees with Columbia, so I think that's an indicator that they're on the same level
I do Law at LSE, and next year, if I do well I have the opportunity to apply for the dual degree programme.
doubt anything outside of the UK makes it there tbh, HYPSM is not just based on quailty of teaching but international recognition and int'l employability
The moniker (correct me if I'm wrong) was created by international applicants from asia
The comparable one would be oxford, cambridge, ucl, imperial, lse
Hmm, yeah I am German (live in England) but so also only have international family friends and I’d still say ucl is slightly below LSE / Oxbridge

For Harvard vs Yale I do see people rejecting Harvard
Yale is still somewhat normal, Harvard isn’t, the people are even crazier

Just out of interest, how would you rank the top 10 unis internationally
You've never met anyone who has applied into IIT have you

The average IIT acceptance rate is lower than 1% (the most competitive ones are well below 0.5%), Indias top students are geniuses (it's a country of 1.5 billion people, the ones you see internationally are smart but they're only from the small rich population of India
Imagine them, but 10x more and quite a bit smarter)
People who get into MIT regularly don't even make it past the first stage of IITs admissions process
So, no, you can't get into IIT by being smart
You basically have to win the lottery to get in while also being smart
(I'm nots saying they're better than the ones you've mentioned, they're obviously not
But, in terms of difficulty to get in, most top asian unviersities clear american ones
And in turn, american ones are far ahead of the UK unis.)
This is just to show you that the quality of a uni has nothing to do with how difficult entry is
Oxbridge will always be top 4 because of their unique teaching style
Their tutorial system has yet to be adopted in a large way anywhere else and is by far the most effective way to teach people
Imperial/LSE are also incredibly strong unis that are about as good as Yale/Princeton despite not being as difficult to get into.
Imperial has an exchange program with MIT though, idt it really means they're at the same level.
yes but ucl also does dual degrees with hku and hku isnt near ucl's level
because i think they're at that level but some dont

MIT, Harvard, Cambridge, Oxford, Princeton, Stanford, Yale, Caltech, Imperial, LSE

I’d say Harvard, MIT (too specialised is to beat Harvard overall imo), Cambridge, Oxford, Stanford, Yale, Princeton, CalTech, Imperial, Lse
I’d say top tier in changing order is, Harvard, Stanford, MIT, Cambridge, Oxford

I have a friend with that offer and Econ LSE and they aren’t sure what to do…
yeah i mean its not that deep ultimately, i think the conclusion we can draw is that we're very lucky to be able to go to these unis
as for 'is this just america and uk' technically no, but i dont think unis from outside of uk/us make it into my top 25, from a general standpoint
but for something like medicine, hku (hong kong university) is very competitive because being a doctor in hong kong is so lucrative, as an example.

Sounds like you should practice the admissions test and then you’ll be good.
All my stats are worse than yours and I got into imperial and ox this year for phys
I have seen people with better stats get rejected tho, I would say it’s a lot about the admissions tests.
I am a current offer holder for imperial physics (2 A-star, 1 A as my requirements)
Predicted A-stars in Maths Physics Further Maths and an EPQ
Youre Alevels are compleltly fine that shouldnt be an issue
Your gcse's are alright but considering youre contextual you should be more than OK in terms of grades
Obviously you will need a good personal statement so assuming you have a good one the only thing that is left is the admissions test
This acedemic year we had the IPAT and no interviews

Im aware the test is changing next year to the ESAT and I would say that preparing for the admissions test is the main thing that will help you get it alongside any interview (This year there wasnt any for physics so I cant say anything about them)
For now all you can really do is do things to better your personal statement and learn the content and practice for your admissions test

What I did for my personal statement was I had a paragraph just purely talking about areas of physics I found interesting and where I found it from (e.g stepen hawkings 'brief history of time' and feynman lectures to learn about QCD, then learning about wiljeczk and weinbergs axion theory based on the Peccei quinn soloution to strong CP problem)
The rest of my personal statement was about different activities ive been involved in and making sure its all relating to physics
(e.g STEM physics/maths prefect, young industrial cadet, competitions ive been in etc.)
Now i dont have enough knowledge to say this was an ideal personal statement however I do have an offer from imperial so take that how you want
Admissions test will be just a case of revising and practicing

Im sure your personal statement will be more than fine considering youre a strong student so ensuring you get a high mark in the test (and any interview that may be as you mentioned in your post) will mean you should likely get an offer
You grades are more than fine, admissions test will be the main thing.
Just grind out the admissions test and prepare for interviews
If they say you have a guaranteed offer, they mean it
Prepare well for the ESAT, which should be similar to the ENGAA/NSAA, and you’ll be fine
Oh nice! If you don't mind, could you share your gcses/predicteds?
4x 9s the rest 5s/6s/7s, 3A* FM, Maf and phys
Congrats on the amazing offer! Both are great options, but consider your interests and career goals
Medical Biosciences at ICL has excellent opportunities, but if your heart's set on CS with AI at York, don't underestimate that path either
Ultimately, follow your passion and what aligns with your future plans.
What time did you get the offer for med bio? Are you an international?
If you want a career to do with AI, software engineering and likewise then do the CS course

The medbio course is fairly new and you should take into consideration that it's 100% online self learning (emodules), you only come in around once a week for 3 hours for group discussion (the only physical contact you'll have  + a day of labs)
If you love the content in medbio so much that you're willing to learn online then go for it
If not, you're set if you do CS and AI - with easier job outlooks
Medbio is not a "professional course" there is no gurantee you'll get a job easily - most would need a msc or PhD for jobs in research/academia
However with good experience and the CS + AI degree you can land a job way easier
Also how did you manage your PS with these entirely different courses?

Just a reminder to be respectful to each other, several of the comments here went too far and have been removed
Like any University: The right grades, the right character, the right devotion to whatever subject you want to study and the fact that you actually apply
Low success rate universities typically reject on the basis that you're not a great fit for the university, a decision that's for your own benefit as much as their own
Just be yourself, if you don't get it then that's not necessarily a bad thing
As for distinguishing yourself from others, having a TRUE devotion towards what you want to study is enough
People apply with A*A*A*A* but don't get in on that simple premise
The interview checks if your mind really is geared towards the subject and their methods
What grades did you get at A-Level and in what subjects? Why do you want to study microbiology?
however, in all honesty I think the personal statement is very important
showing that you have a passion for what you’re applying for and aren’t just applying because “my mummy and daddy told me this will make me a lot of money” is what they’re looking for

showing an interest and even slight knowledge in the subject (not too much because it’s not an essay, but you can tell something anecdotal that shows you know stuff) is good at showing how you’re passionate.
Ok so for context I am an offer holder for their material science course
1 was material science focused (the largest) and detailed actual work that I did directly related to the course
I highly recommend during an introductory course on your subject via online lectures like MITs OpenLearningLibrary
I also did a research project on Nitinol (a shape shifting alloy) this demonstrated knowledge a great degree of interest and were the main topics that we discussed in my interview with them
the 2nd was general skills, I've done a few design and repair projects, use this to lost anything interesting about you that isn't related to the course
For this I'd highly recommend listing ur project/experience and mentioning specific skills and teaching from it
The third was material science again, but specifically about me, why I want to enter this course and my aspirations
I took an environmentalists approach, commenting on the toxic materials used in the tech industry and how a career in material sciences could help me change that.
Very good grades and a true passion for your subject.
My friend got an offer from Imperial and I read her ps
She applied for biochemistry and mostly talked about work experience
She took part in an internship at a research hospital
She also participated in a research contest and talked abt that along with the books she read and why she wanted to study the subject shes applying for
So she talked abt things she did related to biochem and her passion for it
It is easier these days but find the details of your preferred university department’s admissions people and look up their profile
They publish research on a subject and have information for post grad students so reference it in your personal statement

You fulfil the minimum entry requirements if you play your cards right in the exam
It seems this follows a similar selection process as medical sciences:

'Admissions Tutors consider all the evidence available during our rigorous selection process and the College flags key information providing assessors with a more complete picture of the educational and social circumstances relevant to the applicant
Some applicants may be set lower offers and some more challenging ones.'
Best way to prove your devotion is through your grades at this point and especially the personal statement
I'd personally suggest MIT opencoursewave, they are amazing lectures that you can def talk about in your statement.
Yeah, I think some people overthink the PS sometimes and are too focused on making a list of their academic achievements
A lot of students in my year who just went on and on about how they won this award and won something else actually got rejected a lot more than students who spoke about their passion for the subject
Obviously it’s not 100% accurate as it’s just anecdotal, but I think talking about your passion for what you’re applying for looks good
The only academic achievement I spoke about in my PS was teaching myself Italian and getting an A at higher
The rest I spoke about the importance of language in my life and my interest in politics and culture.
I know interviews will be different for everyone, but I just had my interview and every single question I was asked was about something in my personal statement
